text: it's a crisp December morning in Japan
and 30 kilometres south of Tokyo the USS
George Washington is coming home this is
the only American aircraft carrier
stationed outside the u.s. it's only
when you get up close that you really
get a sense of the scale of this ship
it really is immense at 102 thousand
tons it is the biggest most powerful
warship in the world and you can see the
rust the streaks of rust down the side
of it there this ship's been out at sea
for the last three months it's been on
joint maneuvers it's been in the South
China Sea it's been off the coast of the
Philippines assisting with the relief
after typhoon Haiyan hit the Philippines
a couple of weeks ago it's also been on
joint maneuvers with the Japanese
self-defense force off the southern
Japanese coast during this recent
tension with China and now it's finally
coming home I asked US commanders here
if they are concerned by China's new
aircraft carrier the Liaoning which
right now is sailing through the South
China Sea any country building a Carrier
Strike Group capability is going to be
able to significantly shorten the time
frame because they can observe us or you
know you can observe us on a Discovery
Channel show where we show how you carry
straight through operations or your
ships can shadow us and observe us and
get some idea of how we do it on the
other hand to actually get to a large
nuclear-powered carrier carrier
capability is going to we'll take some
period of time
when you get up here on top you get even
more of a sense of the sheer scale of
this ship this flight deck I'm standing
on is more than 330 meters long when
it's at sea with a full complement of
aircraft it can carry 90 fighter jets
and helicopters that's more than most
countries around the world having their
Air Force this really is the physical
embodiment of us
force projection in this part of the
